breaking_news.title: APT37 and ScarCruft Deploy New Malware to Breach Air-Gapped Networks
breaking_news.summary:
North Korean threat actors APT37 and ScarCruft are actively deploying sophisticated new malware tools designed to bridge internet-connected systems with air-gapped networks. The campaigns utilize removable media for data exfiltration and leverage Zoho WorkDrive as a command-and-control infrastructure to maintain persistence and evade detection.

This development represents a significant escalation in state-sponsored espionage capabilities, as it directly targets high-value, isolated environments often used by critical infrastructure and defense sectors. The ability to bypass air-gaps using legitimate cloud services and physical media vectors poses a severe risk to national security and industrial control systems.

breaking_news.title: Juniper Networks Issues Emergency Patch for Critical PTX Router RCE Flaw
breaking_news.summary:
Juniper Networks has released an out-of-band emergency patch for CVE-2026-21902, a critical remote code execution vulnerability affecting PTX Series routers running Junos OS Evolved. The flaw allows unauthenticated attackers to execute code with root privileges by exploiting incorrect permissions in the On-Box Anomaly Detection framework.

Given that PTX routers often sit at the core of enterprise and service provider networks, successful exploitation could lead to total network takeover, traffic interception, and pivoting to adjacent systems. The high CVSS score and the strategic position of these devices make immediate patching essential for global network operators.

breaking_news.title: Google API Key Misconfiguration Exposes Gemini AI Data for Thousands of Organizations
breaking_news.summary:
Researchers discovered that a silent change in Google Cloud Platform API key behavior has exposed thousands of organizations to data theft. Keys previously treated as non-secret billing identifiers are now being used to authenticate to sensitive Gemini AI endpoints, allowing attackers to access private data and run up bills.

The scan identified nearly 3,000 live keys embedded in public code belonging to major financial institutions, security firms, and Google itself. This widespread misconfiguration highlights a critical supply chain risk where legacy developer practices are now being weaponized against high-value AI infrastructure.

breaking_news.title: Aeternum Botnet Hides Command-and-Control Infrastructure in Polygon Smart Contracts
breaking_news.summary:
A new botnet named Aeternum has been identified using Polygon blockchain smart contracts to host its command-and-control (C2) infrastructure. By decentralizing its instructions on a public ledger, the malware avoids traditional server-based takedowns and becomes significantly more resilient against disruption.

This innovative abuse of blockchain technology makes the botnet effectively permanent and harder to detect, as it leverages the same infrastructure used by legitimate decentralized applications. The technique represents a major evolution in botnet persistence, challenging traditional cybersecurity takedown strategies.

breaking_news.title: OpenClaw Vulnerability Allows Malicious Websites to Hijack Local AI Agents
breaking_news.summary:
A critical flaw dubbed 'ClawJacked' in the OpenClaw AI agent platform allows malicious websites to connect to locally running AI agents via WebSocket and seize full control. The vulnerability exploits the assumption that localhost connections are trusted, enabling attackers to bypass rate limits and execute unauthorized commands.

This issue compromises the security of local AI deployments, allowing remote attackers to hijack agents through a simple browser visit. As AI agents become more integrated into local workflows, this vector poses a significant risk to data privacy and system integrity for developers and enterprises using OpenClaw.

breaking_news.title: Canadian Tire Data Breach Exposes Personal Information of 38 Million Users
breaking_news.summary:
Canadian retail giant Canadian Tire disclosed a massive data breach affecting over 38 million customer accounts, discovered in October 2025. The incident compromised an e-commerce database, exposing names, addresses, emails, dates of birth, encrypted passwords, and truncated credit card information.

As one of the largest retail data breaches in Canadian history, the incident raises serious concerns about customer privacy and the security of sensitive personal data in the retail sector. The scale of the breach necessitates widespread notification and potential identity theft protection for millions of affected individuals.

breaking_news.title: North Korean Hackers Target US Healthcare and Education with New Backdoor
breaking_news.summary:
Security researchers have identified a campaign by suspected North Korean digital intruders targeting US healthcare and education organizations with a never-before-seen backdoor. The attacks, active since at least December, involve infecting systems to establish persistent access for espionage or data theft.

The targeting of critical sectors like healthcare and education by state-sponsored actors highlights the ongoing threat to US infrastructure. The use of a novel backdoor suggests an evolving tradecraft designed to bypass existing detection mechanisms in these high-value environments.

breaking_news.title: ShinyHunters Leaks 2 Million Records from Dutch Telecom Odido
breaking_news.summary:
The ransomware group ShinyHunters has leaked 2 million customer records from Dutch telecom provider Odido after the company refused to pay a ransom. The attackers claim to have stolen up to 21 million records in total, threatening to release more data in daily dumps.

This incident underscores the growing trend of data exfiltration as a primary extortion tactic, forcing companies to choose between paying ransoms or facing public data exposure. The breach impacts millions of Dutch citizens, exposing sensitive personal and communication data to the public.
